Situation1: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A heat advisory is issued for the day and an elderly neighbor on the floor lives alone.
Story:
The phone headset presses against my ear as I recite the script for the hundredth time, my voice steady, “Good afternoon, I’m calling to tell you about our new service—” The prospect interrupts, asking about technical details I barely understand. I fumble, glancing at the script, trying to sound confident. My supervisor expects me to handle objections, keep the call going, and never admit uncertainty. My numbers are down this week; I can’t afford to lose another sale.

But outside, the city is shimmering in the heat. The news blares warnings: stay hydrated, check on vulnerable neighbors. I remember Mrs. Lee, two doors down, who lives alone and sometimes forgets to turn on her air conditioner. As a citizen, I know I should check on her, make sure she’s safe. The expectation to help in emergencies tugs at me, but my job demands I stay glued to my desk, headset on, voice cheerful, no matter what.

My hand hovers over the “hold” button, heart pounding. The customer is waiting for answers. Mrs. Lee might be waiting for help. I sit, torn, the weight of both roles pressing in, unsure which demand to answer first.
